content.description: As you walk to the right from the cavern itself look for a ledge that you can just reach (or not quite) with your feet on the ground. The first bolt is over the lip on the ledge. Stick clip it and pull a V2 boulder problem to get up on the ledge (or just pull on the draw A0  style) your reward will be a much more moderate slab moving left at perhaps 5.8 and then up a truly easy beautiful white slab. At the top you may look out to the amazing view of the valley or look down into Gandalf's Cave.
content.protection: 7 bolts to 2 bolt anchor. Long slings are helpful on the traverse section (bolts 2 and 3)
content.location: As you walk to the right from the cavern itself look for a ledge that you can just reach (or not quite) with your feet on the ground. The first bolt is over the lip on the ledge.

content.description: Mettle is the thin and crimpy face to the right of Gypsy Cafe.  Start in front of a small cluster of trees, gain a rail the figure out how to get the rail under your feet. Once your standing on the rail work up the vertical face on smears, crimps, and small feet.  Grab the edge and move slightly right to large positive holds, mantle the low angle shelf and walk off left.
content.protection: I used a mid sized tree to the left of the route and natural features for directional.  A pad, spotter, and courage would work too.

content.description: The first route I noticed when exploring the area with Jay Knower in early September 2013. This line is the most direct and obvious line to ascend The Upper Cliff.  It is also the same crack that forms Gollums Escape (located inside of Gandalf Cave).  Climb the first 20 foot section with lay backing then mantle onto the low angle shelf and get ready for the off width.  The 20 foot off width section is the best and most difficult part of the route.  Getting into the off width is the first crux as it bulges out to give you blind footing.  Towards the top there is a good hand hold inside the crack.  Finish the off width and continue up the Low angle slab another 20 feet and  either cut left and hike off or mount another 4 foot wall and top out to hike off.
content.protection: Mid sized stoppers and #3-#6 cams will give adequate protection.
content.location: This is the most obvious line you will see the moment you arrive at the Upper Cliff.  The easiest way off is to climb all the way to the top after mounting the last 4 foot wall.  You can also scramble left or right at the 4 foot wall (above this wall is a 2 foot loose rock which needs to be avoided and will be removed soon).  If you go left you will get to the entrance of The Gandalf Cave.

content.description: Climb up the blocky rock between the main Cavern Cliff wall and the Block aiming for the right leaning crack in the steeper upper wall. The first half is maybe a 5.5 scramble. Make crux moves through the groove at the bottom left end of the crack. Climb around to the right following the crack. Jam your way up past a wide section and on to the top out. There is a sling anchor on a tree with 2 fixed lower off biners.
content.protection: Normal Crack to tree sling anchor.
content.location: between the main Cavern Cliff Area and the Block. Look up in the steeper headwall for the right leaning crack.

content.description: The Upper Cliff may be the highest vertical rock face of the whole Yellow Jacket area.  It has the potential to hold a few 40-50 foot climbs and even more boulder problems.  Inside of it's main section is where one can find The Gandalf Cave.
